comments:
Build I20021203

The NPE was the cause for testFindType to fail (jdtui.tests).
The tests now run because we turn off autobuild.
To reproduce
- take previous revision of JavaModelUtilTests (setUp)
- ensure an empty workspace is used (note: it seems that the PDE JUnit checkbox
has no effect on clearing the workspace).

Note: the error is VM dependent i.e. it works on 1.4.1 but not on:
java version "1.3.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1)
Classic VM (build 1.3.1, J2RE 1.3.1 IBM Windows 32 build cn131-20020403 (JIT ena
bled: jitc))

You should try the 1.3.1 JVM with the JIT off. I would not be surprise if there
is no more problem. This looks like a VM bug, not a bug in JDT/Core.

I run the tests with -Djava.compiler=NONE as VM args and it worked. One reason
might be the different sequence how tests are executed.

The NPE is reproducible with enabled JIT. Note: you need to run the full
AutomatedSuite to see the NPE.

The JIT in this VM (J2RE 1.3.1 IBM Windows 32 build) has been known to be 
busted for a year.

Closing.

>The JIT in this VM (J2RE 1.3.1 IBM Windows 32 build) has been known to be 
>busted for a year.
Don't they fix such problems in newer VM builds (the build we use is from 20020403).

Could you reproduce the NPE and confirm that it really is the VM?

Note: The problem is that releng runs the tests with that VM. If there is
evidence for the VM to cause this problem could you convince them to use another
VM or disable the JIT?

Reopen - my comment didn't get answered for almost a week and the same problem
(NPE) returned in another test.

Deleting and adding Java projects followed by the builder should not cause this
bug in the builder. If it is a VM problem then you should convince the releng
team to change the VM since the tests crash in J Core code.

We suspect this issue to be a VM JIT bug. Using jdk1.4 makes it go away, or 
simply disabling the JIT makes it go away too.

There have been many issues around the IBM JRE 1.3.1 JIT, and this is 
questionning your using it. You should try to get a better one.

We do not have the luxury of simply changing the JDK we run our tests 
against.  Eclipse 2.x is supposed to run properly under JDK 1.3.1.  Therefor, 
our automated tests run under JDK 1.3.1

We run some of the JDT compiler tests under 1.4.1 but only because they have 
JDK 1.4.1 specific compiler features that they are testing.  I do not believe 
these particular circumstances apply to the debug tests.
Since there have been no additional comments I am closing.
